thread.title: Madison musicians 'Busk the Bike Path' for bike path assault survivor
thread.title_full: Madison musicians 'Busk the Bike Path' for bike path assault survivor

author: LAUREL WHITE | The Capital Times | lwhite@madison.com | @lkwhite
title: Madison musicians 'Busk the Bike Path' for bike path assault survivor
text:
Buy Now PHOTO BY LAUREL WHITE 
The Hoot 'n Annie String Band was one of the local bands that participated in "Busk the Bike Path" on Saturday. 
On Saturday afternoon around 2 p.m., the Hoot ‘n Annie String Band borrowed a 75-foot extension cord and the use of an outlet from a business located just off the Capital City Trail. 
The band — including its electric keyboard, hence the extension cord and outlet — was setting up to perform as part of “Busk the Bike Path,” an event organized by the High Noon Saloon to benefit the victim of a Sept. 12 assault on the Capital City Trail. 
“It’s a sad thing to see people trying to enjoy the outdoors and be so wickedly attacked,” said Jonathan Rosenblum, a Hoot ‘n Annie band member. “You shouldn’t have to have an army to defend you.” 
“We are about our community,” said Daithi Wolfe, another member of the band. “And music is our way to sustain ourselves.” 
“Busk the Bike Path” is the second event the Madison music community has hosted to support the bike path victim. On Oct. 1, a group of musicians came together for “Cover Me,” a benefit concert at High Noon Saloon. 
According to the event’s Facebook page , the “Cover Me” event raised more than $5,000. Proceeds went to the bike path assault survivor and Wisconsin Coalition Against Sexual Assault. 
A little further down the bike path from the Hoot ‘n Annie String Band, guitarist Curtis Goodman was set up with his six string and a guitar case open for donations. A handmade sign propped up next to the case explained that all tips would go to the assault survivor and the Wisconsin Coalition Against Sexual Assault. 
“I decided that I’m at least going to get $15 or $20 before I leave,” Goodman said. 
He thought that was the best thing to do, as the High Noon is offering buskers a free beer in exchange for handing over their “Busk the Bike Path” tips. He wanted to at least cover the price of the beer. 
Goodman said he’s been impressed by the Madison music community’s mobilization of support after the assault. 
“It’s the community — and this is my opportunity to be a part of it,” he said. “I love the bike path, so when I heard it’s not a safe place to be, that really bothered me.” 
That’s what brought violinist Lisa Lathrop out for “Busk the Bike Path” as well. 
“It seems like a good thing to do to raise awareness — to just do something,” she said. Laurel White 
Laurel White covers technology and writes features on music, craft beer and culture for The Capital Times. She joined The Capital Times in 2014, having previously covered politics, agriculture and arts at Wisconsin Public Radio. She graduated with her master's in public affairs reporting from Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism in 2014.
